KEYWORDS: Quaternary; volcanism; climate; volcanic triggering; flexural loading.
Introduction
This paper presents a compilation and analysis of all the available dates for eruptions which have occurred over the last two million years in France and Germany. Nearly 600 events have been tabulated and compared to eliminate superseded dates and combine multiple dates for single eruptions, so that the eruption frequency could be compared statistically with trends in the oxygen isotope curves which reflect the Milankovich climate cycles for this period. This analysis reveals that the frequency of volcanism is far from uniform with clusters of volcanic activity, which can in some cases be clearly linked to the onset of interglacial periods. These results strengthen the case for an association between periods of rapid climate change at the end of glacial cycles and episodes of increased volcanism, given that such phases are intrinsically linked to major changes in regional surface mass distribution due to ice sheets and the extent to which global sea levels impinge on continental shelves. Intra-plate volcanism in western Europe during the Quaternary has been confined to the Massif Central (central and southern France) and the Eifel in western Germany, along with minor eruptive centres in Catalonia, NE Spain (Donville, 1976; Cebriá et al., 2000), the Czech Republic ( Sibrava and Havlı́cek, 1980;
Wagner et al., 1998) and Slovakia ( Simon and Halouzka, 1996; Orlický et al., 1996). Volcanism also appears to have been episodic. Indeed, if volcanism were not episodic it would be reasonable to expect eruptions to be ongoing and not to have ceased in the early stages of the present interglacial. This raises the obvious question: why have these regions had no historically active volcanoes? This study seeks to shed light on this by analysing statistically the frequency of Quaternary eruptions in western Europe (Fig. 1). Cenozoic volcanism in western Europe developed in relation to a complex system of rifts that extends for some 1100 km from the North Sea to the western Mediterranean (Ziegler, 1994). Volcanic fields periodically developed in response to lithosphere thinning and rifting arising from the impingement of the Alpine front (Michon and Merle, 2001). During the Quaternary, periodic changes to the loading of the lithosphere have occurred in the regions surrounding these volcanic fields. These changes resulted from repeated episodes of terrestrial glaciation and deglaciation, driven by the varying orbital parameters of the Earth to the sun, the Milankovich cycles. Over the past 2Ma covered by this study these systematic variations have produced major glacial cycles which first occurred over periods of roughly 41 ka and then after ca. 800 ka at roughly 100-ka intervals. As this study shows, these climatic cycles may be linked to episodic volcanic activity. During a glacial maximum the extensive terrestrial ice caps that formed were triple their present volume, containing about 90 000000 km of water (Williams et al., 1998), resulting in a major fall in eustatic sea level as the total volume of the oceans fell by over 4%. This oxygen isotope curve derived from deep-sea sediments can be used to test for the statistical link between the frequency of volcanic eruptions in western Europe and periods of rapid climate change. As there are relatively few published radiometric dates from the volcanic fields of Catalonia and the Czech Republic, only those for eruptions in the Massif Central, France, and the Eifel, Germany, have been used in this study. Rampino et al. (1979) first suggested that the redistribution of water and ice-sheet loads, during late Quaternary periods of glaciation and deglaciation, may have triggered the eruption of subcritical magma bodies. This was shown by Hall (1982) to have initiated volcanic activity on the sub-Antarctic Marion Island: eruptions only occurred during interglacial stages as a
result of faulting triggered by the unloading as the ice melted. Indeed, Nakada and Yokose (1992) speculated that surface mass redistribution and stress accumulation related to ice ages may be an important trigger and/or accelerator of Quaternary volcanism and active fault movement in island-arcs. Compared to the period before 2Ma they noted a marked increase in the Japanese islands and calculated these changes in lithospheric stress with a simple sawtooth model for 100-ka glacial cycles with 10-ka periods of rapid deglaciation. Tephra layers in deepwater sediment cores from the Mediterranean also show that the frequency of explosive volcanic eruptions correlates with periods of high rates of sea-level change during the last 180 ka (McGuire et al., 1997). Meanwhile on Iceland the eruption rate of basaltic lavas increased by 20 to 30 times the present rate during the last deglaciation (Slater et al., 1998) as a result of the unloading of the ice sheet that covered the island, allowing the upper mantle to depressurise.

On the Iceland Plateau, four major ash zones in marine cores coincide with the last four interglacial oxygen isotope stages (Sejrup et al., 1989). However, Wallrabe-Adams and Lackschewitz (2003) have suggested that this offshore distribution may have been complicated by permanent or seasonally changing ice cover during glacial times, by possibly preventing deepsea deposition of fallout ashes, while Rasmussen et al. (2003) found no correlation with tephra layers only being deposited during interglacials. Glazner et al. (1999) showed that episodic volcanism in eastern California peaked during interglacial periods by correlating these eruptions with the oxygen isotope curve.
Tectonic framework
The Western European rift and related intra-plate volcanism has been related to the evolution of the Alps during the Cenozoic (Merle and Michon, 2001) as the pattern of pre-rift volcanism is roughly parallel to the Alpine front. Volcanism started during the late Cretaceous and peaked during the Palaeocene and Eocene, corresponding to the early Alpine compression which generated lithospheric buckling in a concentric ridge around the Alpine belt at about 60Ma (Michon and Merle, 2001). This is thought to have generated a limited amount of mantle melting induced by doming and resulting adiabatic decompression of the lithosphere. This pre-rift volcanism
stretches from the Bohemian Massif, Rhenish Shield and Upper Rhine to the Massif Central (Michon and Merle, 2001). Later volcanism associated with the initial late Oligocene–early Miocene rifting of the Valencia Trough in NE Spain (Ziegler, 1994) and the opening of the western Mediterranean (Lustrino, 2000) is consistent with this trend. The southeastward roll-back of the Tethys slab may have had a significant effect on the asthenosphere below the Massif Central (Barruol and Granet, 2002).
Massif Central
Volcanism in the southern Massif Central, including the development of the Cantal stratovolcano (Nehlig et al., 2001), has continued since the mid-Miocene (Merle and Michon, 2001). Compared with the overall pattern of Cenozoic volcanism in the Massif Central, eruptions during the last two million years (Table 1) have been confined to just four distinct districts (Fig. 2) within France. The southernmost Escandorgue and Languedoc volcanoes are a scattered chain of small monogenetic cones extending southwards from the Massif Central to the shores of the Mediterranean at Agde. While this chain ceased erupting by 600 ka, the new Cenozoic volcanic province (the Devès area of the Velay district (Michon and Merle, 2001)) remained active until the present glacial cycle. Further northwest, in the Monts Dore, two successive stratovolcanoes developed followed each time by caldera collapse, over periods of firstly 1500 ka and then 750 ka before volcanism finally ceased

The Eifel
The Rhenish Massif in which the Eifel is situated had an early phase of volcanism associated with uplift which peaked at around 42 to 34Ma (Meyer, 1993), during the late Eocene and early Oligocene. This was followed by further uplift at the end of the Oligocene which resulted in the progressive mechanical and thermal thinning of the lithosphere below the region (Ziegler, 1994). This uplift accelerated just after
800 ka (Meyer and Stets, 2002) and was accompanied by renewed eruptions stretching from the Rhine towards Luxembourg (Fig. 3; Table 2). In the Eifel, Quaternary volcanism can be explained without the necessity for significant plume activity (Regenauer-Lieb, 1999). However, seismic images of the upper mantle below the volcanic fields suggest that the upper mantle, like that beneath parts of the Massif Central, is about 150 to 200 C hotter than normal (Ritter et al., 2001) across a region 100 km wide.
The inherent limitation of the dataset
Many of the standard techniques used to date volcanic eruptions, whether directly or indirectly, only cover parts of the Quaternary timespan (Smart, 1991). In particular, it is hard to date events beyond the range of radiocarbon, and those too

young or unsuitable for potassium–argon or argon–argon dating, though thermoluminescence, uranium series and even fission track methods are increasingly being used to close this dating gap. Thus artificial time gaps or biases towards certain time intervals or eruption types may be unwittingly introduced into any list of dated volcanic eruptions (Bryson and Goodman, 1980). The choice of 2Ma as a cutoff date for these listings is arbitrary, but extends well beyond the proposed 780 ka base for the Middle Quaternary (Funnell, 1995) and start of the glacial Pleistocene which Shackleton (1997b) put at about 900 ka.
This transition marks the change from cycles with a period of 41 ka to stronger 100 ka glacial cycles with more extreme glaciations that should produce a better signal and thus correlation with any changes in eruption frequency that are linked to certain phases in the glacial cycle. It is beyond the scope of this paper to consider the possibility that different radiometric systems employ decay constants with discrepancies between them that yield slightly varying dates for the same event (Renne et al., 1998). In our analysis the majority of tabulated ages are derived from the 40K–40Ar and 40–39Ar techniques, while the radiocarbon dates have negligible error ranges compared to older events. The radiocarbon dates in this study have all been converted into approximate ages using the calibration graphs published by Stuiver et al. (1998). Given that some authors quote thermoluminescence dates relative to 1980 rather than 1950BP for radiocarbon dates, in this study all dates have been quoted relative to the year 2000 (Nowell, 2004). Though a single radiocarbon age may represent several true ages on the calibration curve (Pilcher, 1991) we used a simple average of the points intercepted on the Stuiver et al. (1998) graph. In the worst case, this approach will only produce an error of about 150 years (Bowman, 1990), which is still insignificant compared to the precision of most dates used in this study. While high-precision laboratories can in the right circumstances yield radiocarbon dates beyond 40 cal yr BP (Pilcher, 1991) none of the dated eruptions listed here are older than 13.2 ka radiocarbon years (15.9 ka). The supposed gap beyond the limit of radiocarbon dating and before the range of K–Ar and Ar–Ar dating is mainly covered by thermoluminescence dating in France (see Appendix 2). However, Scaillet and Guillou (2004) have recently shown that K–Ar ages can be obtained on samples as young as ca.1.5–2 ka. Although relatively few eruptions remain undated in this interval spanning the last few glacial cycles, most older eruptions have been dated with conventional K–Ar and Ar–Ar methods. This produces a natural bias towards events that yielded potassium-rich mineral phases such as sanidine. Undated events should have a random distribution over time, and approximate eruption ages deduced on French 1:80 000 and later 1:50 000 sheets have rarely been greatly at odds with results obtained later by geochronological methods. In the German Eifel there is clear geological evidence (Meyer, 1994) that during the last 190 ka there have been relatively few eruptions (see Appendix 3), though the Laacher See caldera collapse and pyroclastic eruption near the beginning of the Younger Dryas cooling episode at the end of the last ice age, 12.9–11.7 ka (Taylor et al., 1993) was several orders of magnitude greater than the usual intermittent development of scattered cones in this volcanic field. This is only the third such caldera complex to develop more evolved magmas during the roughly 600 ka of volcanism in the eastern Eifel. The earlier Wehr caldera had two distinct phases, firstly with eruption of the extensive Hüttenberg tephra at ca. 214 ka and then the later Glees tephra ca. 151 ka (Wörner et al., 1988), while the older Rieden caldera is associated with a series of surrounding scoria cones and lava flows that erupted between about 430 and 300 ka (Nowell, 1999). Wörner et al. (1988) consider that these three caldera complexes alone represent more than 95% of the total volume of magma erupted during the Quaternary in the eastern Eifel.
Preliminary data analysis
In order to assess the time distribution of the tabulated volcanic eruption dates, graphs (Fig. 4a,b) were plotted of the estimated intensity functions for the French and German data. In addition
a combined graph (Fig. 4c) was also plotted in order to maximise the available data, given the similar intercontinental setting of these volcanic fields. These intensity functions were estimated using kernel methods, which are one of the most popular techniques of statistical smoothing (Silverman, 1986; Wand and Jones, 1995). Solitary eruptions with a number of published dates were only counted once in the estimated density functions by recalculating them to yield single dates with a 1 error. This was done by assuming that the measurements were independent realisations of the same Gaussian distribution and so the various dates quoted for a given eruption became a mean value with a calculated error derived from the original errors using the formula

The resulting graphs show a number of obvious peaks in volcanism, and it is clear that a number of bursts in volcanic activity mainly confined to the German Eifel are not swamped in the combined plot. This is consistent with many of the separate peaks in the graph of French eruptions representing activity at various times over the last 2Ma in different volcanic fields. However, the existence of often quite large measurement errors meant that providing these graphs was not trivial. This became a kernel deconvolution problem in which the intensity functions are estimated in the presence of measurement errors. Thus our tabulated data values Yi can be written as a series of Yi¼XiþZi values where Xi is a real but unknown eruption date and Zi is the normally distributed measurement error.

Thus it became necessary to estimate the intensity of the real eruption dates rather than the quoted measurements of these tabulated events and so in this case the deconvolving kernel density estimator of Stefanski and Carroll (1990) had to be used. Unfortunately, there are two difficulties to this approach which necessitated the modification of the method. The first difficulty alluded to by Wand and Jones (1995) resulted in the replacement of the standard normal kernel function with one more suitable to deconvolution, while the second copes with the varying measurement error quoted for each tabulated date. The strong narrow peaks near zero in these graphs (Fig. 4) are a consequence of these ad hoc modifications to this method made to take into account the lack of present-day volcanism in our study areas. In addition, the degree to which the data has been smoothed by the selected bandwidths–one for each data point–has been solved rather subjectively to be either twothirds of the Sheather and Jones (1991) automatically chosen bandwidth for data without measurement error or 1.25 times the standard deviation, whichever is the larger.
Associating eruption times with the oxygen isotope series
In order to test whether these peaks in volcanism over time correlated with any phase of the glacial cycle, oxygen isotope data derived from deep ocean cores were used as a proxy for these periodic changes to the global climate and environment. For this study a composite oxygen isotope sequence with values quoted every 3 ka was obtained from the Cambridge University Godwin Laboratory website (http://delphi.esc.cam.ac.uk/ coredata/v677846.html). This sequence was based on three deep ocean cores selected to give the best overall coverage so that ODP core V19-30 (Shackleton and Pisias, 1985) represents the last 340 ka, OPD core 677 (Shackleton et al., 1990) corresponds to the period between 340 and 1811 ka and OPD core 846 (Shackleton et al., 1995a,b) covers the period from 1811 ka until the end of their record at 6137 ka. See Fig. 5 for a comparison of this series and the eruption times.

In order to test for the existence of any association between the oxygen isotope series and the timing of eruptions, the level and slope (difference between consecutive levels) of the oxygen isotope series was identified at the time of each volcanic event by linearly interpolating the time series values. Interest is firstly in whether volcanic events occurred when oxygen isotope levels were high or low, and secondly in whether eruptions corresponded to upward or downward trends in the oxygen isotope series. To test for significance of the collection of levels and slopes so obtained, they were compared with the overall average level and slope of the oxygen isotope time series. A standard one-sample t-test then provides a significance level (p-value) for any association between our proxy for changes in eustatic sea level, global ice volume and general climate conditions with the frequency of volcanism during the
last 2Ma in these parts of intracontinental Europe. While this method has considerable similarities with the technique used by Glazner et al. (1999) it differs by implicitly employing a uniform null distribution of eruption times rather than an exponential distribution. The former seems to us to be better-grounded than the latter. The levels of the oxygen isotope series in the combined French and German dataset spanning the last 2Ma showed considerable significance (Table 3, ‘No lag’ row). However, this simply reflects the higher eruption intensity and raised average isotope levels over the last 650 to 800 ka. Clearly lower isotope levels and prevalence of dated eruptions both occur before the significant transition in the approximate frequency of major climate cycles from 40-ka to the present 100-ka intervals. However, when the dataset was cut down to the last

800 ka this association between these two factors disappeared. A p-value close to significance when the dataset was further cut back to 120 ka reflects the preponderance of eruptions in contemporary, low oxygen isotope, times; see the next Section for further discussion. The second approach uses the slope directions of the oxygen isotope series compared with the eruption data (Table 4, ‘No lag’ row) and produced more clear-cut results with a significant association between the frequency of recorded volcanism and
the climate cycle (Fig. 6). This is strongest over the last 120 ka, which is roughly the interval since the last interglacial and thus the shortest period that contains both strong positive (warming phase) and negative (cooling trends) slopes within the oxygen isotope series. The effect is clearly associated with warming periods as the oxygen isotope ratio falls at the start of interglacial periods between the longer glacial episodes. This becomes clear when the oxygen isotope levels for eruptions that occurred during warming phases are plotted alongside those during cooling phases (Fig. 7). It becomes especially apparent when this graph is limited to slopes greater than 0.05, as there are twice as many eruptions during rapid warming phases. This relationship also shows up when oxygen isotope levels are plotted directly against the slopes when these eruptions occurred (Fig. 8) and when compared to the general scatter of the oxygen isotope series. As the dataset is extended back towards 2Ma the magnitude of this effect becomes somewhat less. This can be explained by the burst of 56 eruptions between 17 and 5 ka, which accounts for over two-fifths of the 126 dated volcanic events during the last 120 ka and which occurred in just a tenth of this interval. When these events were removed from the data, this left no remaining evidence for an association between the timing of eruptions and the slopes of the oxygen isotope time series. This finding may in part be explained by the particular paucity of eruptions during the previous warming phase between 140 and 120 ka. But while there clearly appears to have been little volcanism in the Eifel at this stage, this interval is poorly constrained by radiometric dates with large margins of error. Thus, evidence for the effect of warming phases may simply have been lost, as the dates when these eruptions actually occurred are too uncertain. The one interval without large uncertainties and dates with small error ranges clearly suggests there was an increase in eruptions during the warming phase around 415 and 400 ka. This provides a good reason to wish to obtain better radiometric dates for Pleistocene eruptions as additional test of our statistical hypothesis. Thus to show up clearly a date needs to be determined with a standard deviation less than 5 to 3 ka, which is hard to achieve with favourable conditions. If these events happen to occur towards the beginning or end of such a warming phase this precision would need to fall below 1ka–which is at present unobtainable. These statistical procedures fail explicitly to take into account the uncertainties in these measurements. This may seem paradoxical, but experimenting with our statistical testing procedures in an attempt to account more explicitly for such measurement errors did not appear to yield any tangible results. The quoted errors already account for the possibility of these eruption times being in the wrong place, since each event is taken from a normal distribution centred on when the eruption should have occurred with a standard deviation relative to this time which is not necessarily when the event actually
occurred. Thus, while these measurement uncertainties upset the uniformity of a null distribution for real eruption times, it is difficult to account for properly and would not produce a result that differed much from the one that would be obtained from a completely uniform null distribution. Finally, considering that the periodic changes to the loading of the lithosphere should lag behind those events in the major Quaternary climate cycles that induced these movements in the first place, the data were further tested to see if such a phase shift/relationship appears in the data. Thus the data were reprocessed in the same fashion as before, but with an increasing time lag in order to deduce whether such a relationship can be shown to exist with regard to the frequency of this dataset of western European inter-plate volcanism. This testing of the correlation between the occurrence of eruptions and a lag in the oxygen isotope series had to be limited to 3-ka intervals as this was the resolution at which our dataset was sampled.

The regional effects on the lithosphere of waxing and waning ice sheets, while eustatic sea levels fell and then started to rise along any adjacent continental shelf at the end of major glacial episodes, would have taken the lithosphere some time to respond. On a regional scale this would have been both vertical and with deeper sideways movements, probably extending downwards into the mantle as solid material gradually flowed outwards in response to downloading and crept slowly back in recently unburdened areas. Firstly, the lag was increased in relation to whether the oxygen isotope levels associated with these individual eruptions were higher or lower than their mean (remainder of Table 3). This showed that for the whole of the last 2Ma the significance of the overall oxygen isotope level associated with this volcanism was strong. However, when the dataset was cut back to only 800 ka and then 650 ka the result became significant only as lag was introduced, strengthening as lag was increased beyond 3 ka. Without any lag in the time series, as before, there was no significant correlation between the eruptions and the oxygen isotope data. The same results were obtained for
the analysis limited to the last 120 ka glacial cycle where the significance becomes strong for non-zero lags. This is reasonable because those eruptions associated with warming periods, and hence lower oxygen isotope levels, are being lagged back to times with higher oxygen isotope levels. Secondly, when this relationship was tested on the slope directions of the oxygen isotope series a different pattern emerged (remainder of Table 4). As the lag increases the slope directions associated with individual eruptions start to reverse and begin to lose significance. By the time the lag reaches 9 ka there is no longer any significant link between the intervals at which eruptions occurred and the oxygen isotope series (Fig. 9). This holds for whichever of the first three time intervals (2000, 800 and 650 ka) considered in this study were used to test the relationship between slope directions and increasing the time lag before the supposed onset of volcanic eruptions in response to these changes. Again, this is reasonable, and is consistent with an association between warming periods and volcanic activity being lagged by up to 3 or 6 ka, as much as being relatively instantaneous. Indeed, Jellinek et al. (2004)

Triggering periodic eruptions by changes in lithospheric flexural loading
Since our results show a clear association between the warming phase at the end of two major glacial cycles and significant bursts of volcanic activity, it is worth considering the likely changes during these cycles to the lithosphere in both the Eifel and Massif Central. Shifts in elevation and underlying perturbations would have resulted from distal changes in eustatic sea
level along adjacent parts of the continental shelf and the development and retreat of the surrounding western European ice sheets. However, without a more complex approach similar to those used by Lambeck (1995) and Lambeck et al. (1998), we can only infer whether the likely influence of nearby regional changes in surface mass distribution extended their influence to these volcanic fields (Appendix 1). The extent of the flexural bulge which gives an approximate indication of the extent of influence of either eustatic sea level change or ice loading is easy to calculate, and while these parameters will originate within their margins, these distances may be used to estimate the way in which the local lithosphere would have moved in response to changes in surrounding regions. It is also possible with a simple two-dimensional (2D) model to calculate the approximate displacement at the centre of each region and thus show which would have been more influential (Table 5).

A classic example of flexural uplift is the domal upwarp formerly occupied by the Pleistocene Lake Bonneville in the northern Basin and Range province of the Rocky Mountains. This lake formerly extended 520 km north–south and was up to 200 km wide and has completely dried up, apart from the great Salt Lake, so that its former centre has risen by up to 64m in the process (Crittenden, 1963). While these methods can also be applied to longer-term changes in Quaternary mass distribution and elevation due to the ratcheting effects of glacial and periglacial erosion along with the resulting debris filling sedimentary basins, these changes are cumulative and harder to estimate. Over any single glacial cycle these vertical movements will be much less significant than those associated with the waxing and waning of major ice sheets and related sea-level changes. Furthermore, this pattern of erosion and deposition will in any case reinforce the vertical movements linked to the rapid warming phases at the start of interglacial periods. The ease with which the lithosphere will bend and flex due to a surface load is termed its flexural rigidity (Appendix 1). This depends on the period of time since loading or unloading started and the thermal age of the crust, which Kusznir and Park (1986) define as the time since the last major thermo-tectonic event and after which the lithosphere progressively cools. Studies of oceanic lithosphere also show that as the loading time increases the effective flexural rigidity will steadily drop (Watts and Zhong, 2000) and thus the wavelength over which a load is supported will narrow as the maximum downloading
amplitude increases in the middle of the load. Given that considerable inertia must be overcome when the lithosphere is loaded, it has been considered that a surface will not sink under the weight of a small load less than 100 km across. However, large-scale open-cast mining can produce measurable uplift (Klein et al., 1997) by locally unloading the crust over a much narrower width than otherwise might be supposed if such unloading or small loads were supported by the finite strength of the lithosphere spreading it over a wider area.
Inferred changes to the lithosphere in the Eifel and Massif Central
The effects of neighbouring ice sheets and the fall in eustatic sea level on surface levels in the Eifel and Massif Central can be inferred from the relative magnitude and position of the flextural bulges around these regions using the equations in Appendix 1. Normally, these have been based on theWeichselian (Devensian) glacial maximum, as the last glacial stage has left the most evidence on which to base this simple reconstruction (Fig. 10). However, the maximum extent of these ice sheets varied during each glacial stage and some extended further south (Svendsen et al., 1999) than those that developed during the Weichselian. Thus the Fennoscandian ice sheet extended across northern Germany by at least an additional 300 km

during the Saalian and by nearly the same distance during the earlier Elsterian (Anglian) glacial stage. Considering its relative proximity to the Eifel, this frontal lobe covering Jutland and Friesland can be modelled as a separate ice sheet during these earlier glacial stages. At its maximum extent Anglian glaciation in Britain extended roughly 100 km nearer to the Eifel and, compared to the relatively thin ice surge down the coast of eastern England during the Devensian, would have had some influence. Considering the inherent ambiguities in the possible flexural rigidity values for the continental lithosphere underlying each area, each model was calculated with two values. These depend on whether or not the cumulative effects of repeated loading and unloading events during the more extreme 100 ka glacial cycles of the last 800 ka has reduced the effective rigidity of the lithosphere over what are normally considered to be relatively short loading intervals. Thus the lithosphere under central Scandinavia and the Baltic was considered to have a flexural rigidity of either 1025 or 1024N m, while other areas were modelled with values of either 1024 or 1023N m (Fjeldskaar, 1997), apart from the Alps which are considered to be thermally young (Kusznir and Park, 1986) and thus might have a flexural rigidity as low as 1022N m. However, this is unlikely as Karner and Watts (1983) calculated the flexural rigidity of the Alps to be between 1023 and 1024N m, apart from the southern Alps (at 2.4 1022 to 1.9 1023N m). These values are similar to the values quoted by Lavier and Steckler (1997). While the effects of volcanism might have raised the temperature of the lithosphere below the volcanic fields in this study it is unlikely this would have been widespread enough to have a significant effect. Indeed, seismic imaging below the Eifel indicates there is a narrow zone only 100 km wide with a temperature excess of between 150 and 200 C, to a depth of at least 400 km, as P wave velocities are attenuated by up to 2% (Ritter et al., 2001). The major areas of lithospheric loading were Fennoscandia, Britain and Ireland, Cantal and Monts Dore, the Alps and Jutland and Friesland. The more minor areas of unloading (by falling sea level) included the southern North Sea, the English Channel and the eastern margin of the Bay of Biscay. Smaller regions of exposed continental shelf such as the Golfe du Lion along the Mediterranean coast of southern France would have had an insignificant effect on the main volcanic fields in this study; however, local changes in sea level may have influenced the timing of volcanism around Agde in the Hérault and nearby Catalonia. Within the Massif Central, glaciation was extensive enough (Etlicher and De Göer de Herve, 1988) to consider modelling it alongside more distal effects, while glaciation in the Pyrénées would have probably been confined to a very narrow band less than 10 km wide apart from a few valley glaciers (Andrieu et al., 1988) which extended up to 40 km northwards from the central axis. The extent of Alpine glaciation was derived from Florineth and Schlüchter (1998, 2000) and average thickness of this ice cap implied by these studies would have been around 1000m, while the parameters of the major ice sheets were obtained from Fjeldskaar (1997) and adjusted in light of the new reconstruction of the southern limit of the northwest European ice cap (Svendsen et al., 1999). Since the contoured thickness of the Fennoscandian ice sheet only declines rapidly at the extreme margins of the late Weichselian model (Fjeldskaar, 1997), the earlier Saalian and Elsterian ice sheets covering Jutland and Friesland can on this basis be estimated to have been at least 1000m thick. The models presented by Siegert et al. (1998) cover this region with a greater average ice thickness, even though only northern and eastern Jutland were glaciated during theWeichselian, so these models are more appropriate for earlier glacial stages. At glacial max-
ima the eustatic sea level was assumed to be below 100m and it was also assumed that areas of continental shelf without ice sheets depressing their surface were completely exposed. This palaeogeography at the time of the last glacial maximum (Fig. 10) is broadly outlined by the Commission for the Geological Map of the World (1999) and in France is covered in greater detail by Petit-Maire et al. (1999). The estimated downloading at the centre of the Fennoscandian ice sheet at around 540m (Table 5) is consistent with the ca. 600m predicted by Lambeck et al. (1998), and the 270m of uplift during the last 10 ka (Wieczerkowski et al., 1999). The simple flexural models used in this paper suggest that given a relatively rigid lithosphere the Chaı̂ne des Puys would have been depressed by both local and Alpine ice caps reinforced by the small flexural budges from the English Channel and Atlantic coast of France along the Bay of Biscay. If the flexural rigidity had been 10 23N m apart from local downloading there would only have been moderate uplift from the flexural budge generated by the Alps (Table 5). Had this been the case, then any change in the estimated 50m average thickness for the ice cover in the Monts Dore and Cantal (Fig. 2) would become significant. This is very poorly constrained and assumes that the region’s valley glaciers were at most 200m thick while intervening areas were only lightly covered in ice and permanent snow. Some of the region’s youngest postglacial eruptions occurred within the eastern margin of this glaciated area. The results for the Eifel are more complex (Table 5), since, if the lithosphere had been relatively rigid (1024Nm), the flexural uplift due to the more distant Fennoscandia and Alpine ice sheets would have been slightly diminished by sagging away from the southern North Sea and English Channel. During the earlier Saalian stage, and to a slightly lesser extent during the earlier Elsterian stage, the Eifel would have been downloaded significantly by the local lobe of ice over Jutland and Friesland. If the flexural rigidity had been lower, only the Alps and the Jutland and Friesland ice sheets would have generated moderate uplift in their flexural bulges.
Discussion
Our statistical results analysis suggests that increased volcanism between 415 to 400 ka and 17 to 5 ka can be correlated with the warming phases which ended the last Weichselian (Devensian–MMIS 2) and the earlier Elsterian (Anglian– MMIS 12) glacial stages. The significance of these two intervals may be no coincidence, as Ruddiman et al. (2005) found that the variation in orbital insolation during the present interglacial compared with MMIS 5, 7 and 9, is more closely matched by MMIS 11 as a result of low eccentricity which modulates the precession at 413 ka. This view is strengthened by an ice core analysis from Greenland, which clearly shows an increase in recorded distal volcanism between 17 and 6 ka that is especially marked between 15 and 8 ka (Zielinski et al., 1996). Enhanced volcanism around the northern hemisphere would support the idea that the readjustment of crustal stress patterns during glacial unloading led to this increase in the rate at which eruptions occurred. Indeed, Houtgast et al. (2005) have shown a marked increase in fault displacement rates in the southern Netherlands around 15 to 10 ka, probably associated with glacial unloading, which would tie in with this pattern of volcanism. Conversely, the stresses associated with the late Weichselian build-up of ice may explain the rise in volcanism between 35 and 22 ka (Zielinski et al., 1996).

Such evidence is consistent with a surge in volcanism just after the last Icelandic ice cap mainly melted, when depressurisation of the upper mantle produced magma at 20 to 30 times the rate of present eruptions (Slater et al., 1998). This melt was generated following less than the 600m of uplift suggested by Jull and McKenzie (1996), since the ice cap covering Iceland was thinner than the 2000m supposed. It was probably only 1500 to 1000m thick, which would imply only about 350m of postglacial uplift (Bourgeois et al., 1998). In the centre the response would be almost purely isostatic as the ice cap waxed and waned. However, this massive depressurisation of the upper mantle did produce a marked shift in the trace element composition between Icelandic magmas erupted during interglacial and glacial periods (Slater et al., 1998). It is possible that the magmas erupted in the Massif Central and the Eifel might have been generated by a decompression mechanism similar to that on Iceland, given that these volcanic fields are on the periphery of regions that underwent rapid changes at the end of glacial stages. It is also interesting to note that all three calderas that have developed in the eastern Eifel (Appendix 3) formed during warming phases at the end of major glacial cycles. Both Laacher See (13.1 ka) and Reiden (409 to 398 ka) occurred at times that we can correlate with a statistically significant increase in volcanism associated with warming phases. Furthermore, the Reiden caldera and the Hüttenberg tephra, which forms the bulk of the Wehr caldera, erupted respectively after the Elsterian (MIS 12) and Saalian (MIS 8) glacial stages. This suggests that nearby rapid uplift due to the melting of ice sheets can trigger a short burst of volcanic activity, either as these single major events or as a series of scattered occurrences much as the 54 eruptions that occurred in the Massif Central between 17 and 5 ka (Appendix 2). Conversely, the Younger Dryas stadial conditions between ca. 12.9 and 11.7 ka (Zielinski et al., 1996) may have been influenced by the climatic impact of the increased volcanism picked up in Greenland associated with the end of glacial times at around ca. 14.7 ka (Bryson and Goodman, 1980). However, the magnitude of volcanic activity just prior to, and at the inception of, the Younger Dryas is not much different from the enhanced volcanism near its end and during the millennium following it and fails to suggest a direct causal link (Zielinski et al., 1996). This paradox is resolved if one considers that the Younger Dryas occurred within an overall warming trend resulting from orbital forcing associated with a Milankovich cycle, so that this interval can be viewed merely as a temporary retardation in conditions due to this increased volcanism at the start of an interglacial phase. In a similar way, Ruddiman et al. (2005) compared the trend of the early part of MIS 11 with that for the present interglacial to suggest ancient anthropogenic CO2 and CH4 emissions have kept modern global temperatures 2 C warmer than might have been expected. Given that the Massif Central had small localised ice caps, this could explain why these volcanic fields have had more Quaternary eruptions than the Eifel. Alternatively, increased volcanism during the transition from glacial to interglacial times could have been driven by the more general disturbance of the lithosphere and upper mantle. Relaxation would have occurred after the material forced sideways as these ice loads built up started to return. Indeed, Klemann and Wolf (1999) have modelled the ductile deformation in the uppermost 100 km of the lithosphere generated by the Fennoscandian ice sheet and show that even 1500 km from the centre of loading there were significant variations in maximum shear stress over the glacial cycle. Their model also predicts a present day þ500mGal free-air gravity anomaly with a 2 mGal rate of annual change, along with some horizontal displacement and sinking of about 1mm a year at this distance. However,
as a result of regional tectonic uplift the Rhenish Massif is actually rising by over 1mmyr 1 (Ritter, 1997), while similar areas in eastern Britain south of the Devensian ice limit are now sinking at around 1 to 2mmyr 1 (Shennan andWoodworth, 1992). This pattern is due to very rapid postglacial uplift followed by eustatic sea-level rise and the faster residual rise of the former centres of glaciation (Lambeck, 1995). While the Rhenish massif would have experienced limited post-Weichselian tectonic uplift, the rapid submergence of the southern North Sea (Shennan and Woodworth, 1992) in the Netherlands would have resulted in the local downloading compared with the Eifel. After the end of some earlier glacial stages this sinking would have been countered by uplift generated as ice covering Jutland and Friesland melted. This differential uplift at the end of the last ice age combined with rising sea levels would explain the downstream convergence of the Rhine and Meuse floodplains in their Netherlands delta. The higher upstream surface is thought to have formed around the Last Glacial Maximum, while the lower surface dates from the Younger Dryas stadial (Törnqvist, 1998), by which time most of the northern European ice sheets had melted. Thus there is no need to invoke the idea (Törnqvist, 1998) that the relative level of the sea into which a river flows controls upstream fluvial incision many hundreds of kilometres inland, as this process would have simply been driven by the relative postglacial movements of the lithosphere. In order to improve our understanding of the possible links between the present 100-ka glacial cycles over roughly the last 800 ka (if not the earlier 41 ka cycles) and the timing of such inter-plate eruptions there is a clear need for more precise radiometric dating. In the meantime, while the existing data are far from satisfactory there is no need to guess the ages of those eruptions which are undated (Glazner et al., 1999) in order to produce a more clear-cut statistical picture. Apart from the obvious possibility of bias in the selection of these additional dates, it does not reveal the true nature of the data from which their conclusions are drawn. Glazner et al. (1999) merely list the references they used to compile their data set on a website rather than opening up a proper tabulation where each date can be scrutinised, given that some may be superseded or be multiples of the same event. Given the relatively fleeting duration of warming phases associated with Quaternary interglacials, at around 15 or 18 ka, the resolution of radiometric dating of volcanic eruptions would ideally need to fall to less than 3 ka. This would allow a far clearer statistical picture to emerge than is presently obtainable, not only with regard to any other links with this pattern but in improving the overall quality of Quaternary terrestrial stratigraphy. In addition, these radiometric results need to be presented to a higher standard with locations and stratigraphic relationships clearly set out, to avoid the possibility of confusing errors in compiling and testing such statistical datasets. While our analysis provides evidence for a relationship between warming cycles and enhanced volcanism, which parallels the conclusions of recent studies of continental magmatism (e.g. Glazner et al., 1999; Jellinek et al., 2004), this relationship is actually contrary to that which has recently been recognised in an analysis of the relationships between volcanic particulates and climate signals in polar ice cores (Bay et al., 2004). Bay et al. (2004) identify a link between volcanic ash layers and the onset of millennial cooling events, similar to conclusions drawn previously by Rampino et al. (1979) and McGuire et al. (1997), among others. There is not necessarily any conflict between these sets of conclusions, as it may simply reflect the contrasting nature of the volcanoes that are affected by global phase of warming (removal of ice loads from conti-

Our analysis also strengthens the argument that the onset of volcanism may be highly sensitive to external forcings (e.g. Jupp et al., 2004; Mason et al., 2004), which is an area that needs much further study.
Conclusions
This analysis clearly shows that volcanism in western Europe was episodic and correlates with two warming phases at the onset of interglacials, as do the three significant caldera-forming events in the eastern Eifel, Germany. These bursts of volcanism were most probably triggered by the rapid adjustment of the surrounding lithosphere as neighbouring ice sheets melted, in response to orbital forcing inducing major warming phases at the end of glacial cycles. The environmental impacts of volcanism at the end of the last Weichselian (Devensian) glacial stage may have influenced the development of the Younger Dryas, when harsher climatic conditions briefly retarded the overall warming trend at the start of the present interglacial.

abstractText: Intra-plate volcanism in western Europe shows statistically significant episodicity during the Quaternary period. By comparing the known ages for eruptions in France and Germany, which are compiled here, with a composite oxygen isotope record, we have investigated the link between this episodic volcanism and the climate record over the last two million years. We show that increased volcanism between 415–400 ka and 17–5 ka correlates with warming phases at the end of the last Weichselian (Devensian) and earlier Elsterian (Anglian) glacial stages. The three significant caldera explosions in the eastern Eifel, Germany, are all associated with warming phases at the onset of interglacials. The growth and decay of nearby ice sheets suggest that surface changes in continental mass distribution during glacial Milankovich cycles could provide a mechanism for this correlation by means of the distal effects of flexural loading on the lithosphere.
